questions.question: What is a computer?
questions.explanation: Computer: programmable electronic device processing input data into output. Components: CPU (processor), memory, storage, I/O devices. Purpose: automate tasks, store information, process data. Evolution: from room-size mainframes to personal devices. Ubiquitous: phones, laptops, servers, embedded systems. Impact: revolutionized society.

questions.question: What manages computer resources?
questions.explanation: Operating System manages hardware resources. Functions: process management, memory management, file systems, I/O control. Examples: Windows, macOS, Linux, Android. User interface: command-line or graphical. Resource allocation: fair, efficient. Abstraction: hides hardware complexity. Essential: every computer needs OS.

questions.question: What executes program instructions?
questions.explanation: CPU executes program instructions. Components: control unit (directs), ALU (arithmetic logic). Clock: synchronizes operations. Speed: measured in GHz (billions cycles/second). Multiple cores: parallel processing. Thermal: generates heat, needs cooling. Performance: bottleneck often here.

questions.question: What temporarily stores data?
questions.explanation: RAM temporarily stores running program data. Speed: very fast access. Volatile: loses data on power-off. Capacity: KB to GB (modern). Cost: expensive per GB. Speed-capacity tradeoff: faster = more expensive. Upgrade: improves multitasking. Sufficient RAM: prevents slowdowns.

questions.question: What permanently stores data?
questions.explanation: Storage permanently holds data. Types: HDD (mechanical), SSD (electronic), optical. Speed: slower than RAM. Capacity: GB to TB. Persistent: survives power-off. Reliability: critical importance. Backup: essential protection. Full storage: slows performance.

questions.question: What connects computer parts?
questions.explanation: Motherboard connects all components. Contains: CPU socket, RAM slots, connectors, chipset. Buses: transfer data between components. Power distribution: provides electricity. Expansion: add cards (GPU, network). Failure: computer non-functional. Upgrade: limited options.

questions.question: What powers the computer?
questions.explanation: Power Supply provides electrical power. Converts: AC to DC for components. Wattage: must handle system needs. Efficiency: reduces waste heat. Failure: complete shutdown. Upgrade: necessary for power-hungry components. Capacity: headroom prevents overload.

questions.question: What input device enters text?
questions.explanation: Keyboard inputs text and commands. Layout: QWERTY standard (US). Types: mechanical, membrane, wireless. Ergonomic: RSI prevention. Shortcuts: productivity boost. Gaming: mechanical preferred for tactile feedback. Error: typos common.

questions.question: What points on screen?
questions.explanation: Mouse controls cursor on screen. Types: mechanical, optical, wireless, trackpad. Precision: select small items. Ergonomic: hand position matters. Sensitivity: adjustable. Left/right click: different actions. Scroll: wheel navigates documents.

questions.question: What displays information?
questions.explanation: Monitor displays visual output. Resolution: pixels (width x height). Size: measured diagonally. Types: LCD, OLED, CRT (obsolete). Refresh rate: smoothness (Hz). Color depth: colors available (bits). Eye strain: monitor position important. Multiple: productivity boost.
